Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-India Planning Visit: Collaborative Research on Polyactic Acid Ionomers.
Award.AbstractNarration:
1037189
Sachin Velankar

This award supports the U.S.-India Planning Visit: Collaborative Research on Polylactic Acid(PLA)Ionomers. US PI Velankar, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Pittsburgh will visit Professor Ashish Lele, Division of Polymer Science and Engineering, National Chemical Laboratory (NCL), Pune to evaluate the facilities at NCL and conduct proof-of-concept experiments in summer 2010. The outcome will be the submission of research proposals to the National Science Foundation (NSF)'s Materials World Network Program and to the Government of India's Department of Science and Technology (DST), NSF-DST Joint Program.

The intellectual merit of the research is that it will apply the well- developed idea of ionomers to PLA, one of the most important biodegradable and renewable polymers. This will advance the materials science of PLA and open up new opportunities to improve and control its properties. The long-term goal is to develop PLA ionomers, which have a potentially wide range of applications for controlling rheological properties, thermomechanical properties, and the biodegradability of PLA. Dr. Velankar has the relevant expertise in ionomers, rheology, and polymer compatibilizers; Dr. Ashish Lele provides complimentary expertise as the lead investigator for NCL's PLA related research. The National Chemical Laboratory has extensive resources for polymer characterization and a significant research effort underway for advancing PLA technologies.

The broader impacts of this research are the fostering of collaboration between the PI and colleagues at the University of Pittsburgh with collaborators at NCL, giving opportunities to US graduate and undergraduate students to work at one of India's premier laboratories, and expanding the applications of renewable polymers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this travel grant was to explore the potential for collaborative research with scientists at the National Chemical Laboratory, Pune, India, on the topic of renewable polymers. Specifically, we seek to develop ionic modification as a strategy for modifying the flow properties of polylactic acid.

One goal of this travel grant was to obtain preliminary evidence that the proposed chemistry for ionic modification was sound. The proposed chemistry consists of reacting the polylactic acid molecules with maleic anhydride in a solution polymerization, converting the anhydride into acid by ring-opening, and then neutralizing the acid with an acetate salt such as sodium acetate. All of this would be accomplished in a “single-pot” reaction. The PI, along with the project assistant from NCL, Pune, Ms. Amruta Kulkarni, conducted experiments to test this chemistry. The results were not unequivocal: it does appear that there the maleation and acidification did proceed, but there is likely to be significant chain scission (as judged by a decrease in molecular weight).

A second, and more important, goal of this travel grant was a logistical one: to examine the facilities (especially housing) at the National Chemical Laboratory to judge whether they would be suitable for a U.S. student to work there for a period of about 1 year. This is so that the research collaboration can also serve as an opportunity for U.S. nationals to participate in international research opportunities. This logistical question has been resolved unequivocally. The facilities at NCL (and even more at IISER; see below) are ideal for U.S. students to visit even for extended periods.

In an increasingly globalized world, engineers and scientists in the U.S. must collaborate and compete with counterparts abroad and such experiences must become a key ingredient of graduate programs in the future.

The PI also gave one research seminar and one educational tutorial to students and post-docs at the National Chemical Laboratory. The research seminar was on jamming of particles at the liquid/liquid interface. The educational tutorial was on the rheology of particulate suspensions, combined with hands on demonstrations of phenomena such as shear thickening and sedimentation fronts. This latter tutorial has now been used for educational purposes in the PI’s home institution (University of Pittsburgh) to train undergraduate research (REU) students.

Furthermore, the PI also visited (Indian Institute of Science Education and Research (IISER), Pune. This is a relatively new University (one of several IISERs) established all over India. The research, education, and accommodation facilities at IISER are excellent making it an ideal location as a study abroad site for University of Pittsburgh undergraduates. The PI is working with the International Studies program at the University of Pittsburgh to establish this relationship.
